Knowledge Point: Contrast the paradigm in \REF{bkm:Ref59175832} with a family of words also based on the root do:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The forms in \REF{bkm:Ref59176157} can be thought of as a partial \isi{word family} because they are all based on the same root. However, they are not a paradigm. There are several reasons this list of forms is not a \isi{paradigm}. First, they do not vary according to any coherent semantic dimension – their meanings are logically independent of one another: reversative, reiterative, ability, etc. Second, the meaning elements they express may combine with one another, for example undoable combines the notions of reversative and ability; redoable combines reiteration with ability. Forms such as un-redo, re-undo, and re-undoable, though perhaps odd-sounding out of context, are also conceivable members of this family. Third, none of the affixes that define a word family are required for the root to be used in discourse. Fourth, these forms do not have analogies for every English verb. For example forms like *resee, *unremember, *bleedable and many others are extremely difficult to find appropriate communicative contexts for. Finally, the forms undo and redo are verbs, just like the root do. As such, they also occur in the five possible inflectional forms for English verbs: undid, redoing, undone, redoes, undo, and so on. In other words, the affixes that define the word family may occur with each other, and with the inflectional forms in the paradigm.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In contrast, the inflections, as given in \REF{bkm:Ref59175832}, are mutually exclusive – a form cannot logically express present tense and past tense at the same time; 3\textsuperscript{rd} person singular and non-3\textsuperscript{rd} person singular at the same time, and so on. Thus forms with multiple inflections are impossible: *diding, *doinged, *done-ing, *dids, *dones, etc. Note that these forms are strictly uninterpretable; they do not just “sound odd out of context” the way un-redo and re-undo might.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The Kagayanen words in \REF{bkm:Ref59345903} are all verb stems, ready to be inflected with one of the possible inflectional affixes (indicated by the dash in front of each form). They all have different, though related, meanings. Note that the morphological processes that give rise to these forms (pa-, ng-, -an, -ay and reduplication) may combine with one another to produce even more complex forms, as illustrated in the last three examples in \REF{bkm:Ref59345903}. These stem-forming morphological processes\is{stem-forming morphology}, and others, are a rich resource available to Kagayanen speakers to create complex and nuanced meanings.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: There is a difference between \isi{semantic transitivity}\is{transitivity!semantic} and grammatical transitivity. Semantic transitivity has to do with situations being communicated, whereas grammatical transitivity has to do with grammatical structures used to depict those situations. The two types of transitivity do not necessarily coincide. For example, English constructions such as she already ate, or he drank of the water of bitterness present semantically transitive\is{semantic transitivity}\is{transitivity!semantic} situations (someone eating or drinking something) in grammatically intransitive constructions (there is no direct object). Something similar occurs in Kagayanen. Situations that seem to require an Undergoer and a distinct Controller may be expressed in an intransitive construction, with the Undergoer simply omitted or presented in the non-absolutive case, preceded by ta or ki. We describe such constructions as detransitive\is{detransitive constructions}. Such constructions are used when there is an Undergoer, but it is less salient in the communicative situation than the Actor in some way. The Actor is presented as the most affected participant, and the Undergoer, if present at all, is presented as less central in some way, either by being indefinite, non-specific, incompletely affected, and so on. Of course, the big difference between English and Kagayanen is that English does not mark grammatical transitivity on the verb, whereas Kagayanen does. The verb eat is the same whether it occurs in a transitive (SUBJ eats OBJ) or intransitive (SUBJ eats) frame. In Kagayanen, however, the verb in a detransitive construction is explicitly marked as intransitive. Examples \REF{bkm:Ref118364790} and \REF{bkm:Ref125017724} illustrate detransitive constructions from the corpus. Additional examples are found throughout this grammar.
Content 1: \gsrc Pagtapos nay igma, \textbf{gatan-aw kay ta sini}. | \gll Pag-tapos nay igma, \textbf{ga-tan-aw} \textbf{kay} \textbf{ta} \textbf{sini}. | \gls NR.ACT-finish 1p{excl.gen} lunch T.R-look 1p{excl.abs} NABS movie | \glt ‘After finishing our lunch, \textbf{we watched a movie}.’
Content 2: \gsrc Piro tama man na \textbf{mga inay na galuag man ta kaanlao}... | \gll Piro tama man na \textbf{mga} \textbf{inay} \textbf{na} \textbf{ga-luag} \textbf{man} \textbf{ta} \textbf{kaanlao}... | \gls but many also LK PL mother LK I.R-watch EMPH NABS lunar.eclipse | \glt ‘But there were many \textbf{mothers who watched a lunar eclipse} ...’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref118364790} is part of a story about what the Actors did. It is not about any particular movie. In terms of \citealt{halliday2004}, sini, `movie', simply describes the ``range" over which the watching took place; the Actors engaged in ``movie watching". Therefore the Actor is presented as absolutive (kay `absolutive, first person plural exclusive'), and the verb is inflected as intransitive (ga- `intransitive, realis'). Similarly, example \REF{bkm:Ref125017724} is about the mothers, and not any particular lunar eclipse. In this case, the mothers are the Head of a modifying (relative) clause. As will be discussed in \chapref{chap:clausecombining}, the Head of a relative clause must be the absolutive of that clause. Therefore, the verb inside the relative clause must be in an intransitive form with the Actor understood as the absolutive.
Content 1: \gsrc Pagtapos nay igma, \textbf{gatan-aw kay ta sini}. | \gll Pag-tapos nay igma, \textbf{ga-tan-aw} \textbf{kay} \textbf{ta} \textbf{sini}. | \gls NR.ACT-finish 1p{excl.gen} lunch T.R-look 1p{excl.abs} NABS movie | \glt ‘After finishing our lunch, \textbf{we watched a movie}.’
Content 2: \gsrc Piro tama man na \textbf{mga inay na galuag man ta kaanlao}... | \gll Piro tama man na \textbf{mga} \textbf{inay} \textbf{na} \textbf{ga-luag} \textbf{man} \textbf{ta} \textbf{kaanlao}... | \gls but many also LK PL mother LK I.R-watch EMPH NABS lunar.eclipse | \glt ‘But there were many \textbf{mothers who watched a lunar eclipse} ...’

Knowledge Point: The inflectional prefix ga{}- is the most common form for \isi{dynamic intransitive events} on the storyline in narratives. In this usage, the aspectual interpretation is perfective\is{perfective aspect}, as in the first clause of example \REF{bkm:Ref396718263}:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Gapit} kay anay ta dawisan tak \textbf{ganampara} pa mga gurmiti ta sid-anan. | \gll \textbf{Ga-apit} kay anay ta dawis-an tak \textbf{ga-ng-tampara} pa mga gurmiti ta sid-anan. | \gls I.R-stop.off 1P.EXCL.ABS first/for.a.while NABS point-NR because I.R-PL-goggles INC PL crew NABS viand | \glt `We stopped off first at the point (of the island) because the crew were still spear fishing for viand.’

Knowledge Point: However, predicates inflected with ga{}- may be understood as imperfective\is{imperfective aspect}. For example, the second occurrence of ga- (ganampara) in \REF{bkm:Ref396718263} is within an adverbial clause expressing a backgrounded, non-storyline event. The imperfective aspect interpretation is reenforced by the use of the incompletive adverbial pa.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Gapit} kay anay ta dawisan tak \textbf{ganampara} pa mga gurmiti ta sid-anan. | \gll \textbf{Ga-apit} kay anay ta dawis-an tak \textbf{ga-ng-tampara} pa mga gurmiti ta sid-anan. | \gls I.R-stop.off 1P.EXCL.ABS first/for.a.while NABS point-NR because I.R-PL-goggles INC PL crew NABS viand | \glt `We stopped off first at the point (of the island) because the crew were still spear fishing for viand.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref396718461} illustrates one use of ga- in which the interpretation may be either \isi{inceptive} or imperfective. The event of walking is ongoing in the story. After the sentence illustrated in \REF{bkm:Ref396718461}, the story describes crossing a river on stepping stones and other events that happened on the way to the community of Teresa. Therefore, example \REF{bkm:Ref396718461} may be understood as a (perfective) inceptive “we began to walk again” or it could mean “we were walking again.” In either case it does not describe the entire event of walking to Teresa, and therefore is not perfective:
Content 1: \gsrc Pag-abot nay ta liyo, \textbf{gapanaw} kay eman munta ta Teresa. | \gll Pag-abot nay ta liyo, \textbf{gapanaw} kay eman m-punta ta Teresa. | \gls NR.ACT-arrive 1P.EXCL.GEN NABS other.side I.R-go/walk 1P.EXCL.ABS as.before I.V.IR-go NABS Teresa | \glt `When we arrived on the other side (of a river), we were/began walking again as before going to Teresa.’
Content 2: \gsrc Pag-abot nay ta liyo, \textbf{gapanaw} kay eman munta ta Teresa. | \gll Pag-abot nay ta liyo, \textbf{gapanaw} kay eman m-punta ta Teresa. | \gls NR.ACT-arrive 1P.EXCL.GEN NABS other.side I.R-go/walk 1P.EXCL.ABS as.before I.V.IR-go NABS Teresa | \glt `When we arrived on the other side (of a river), we were/began walking again as before going to Teresa.’
Content 3: \gsrc Pag-abot nay ta liyo, \textbf{gapanaw} kay eman munta ta Teresa. | \gll Pag-abot nay ta liyo, \textbf{gapanaw} kay eman m-punta ta Teresa. | \gls NR.ACT-arrive 1P.EXCL.GEN NABS other.side I.R-go/walk 1P.EXCL.ABS as.before I.V.IR-go NABS Teresa | \glt `When we arrived on the other side (of a river), we were/began walking again as before going to Teresa.’

Knowledge Point: With roots that describe properties or states, ga{}- expresses the process of entering the state (inchoative)\is{inchoative}. Examples \REF{bkm:Ref119937645} and \REF{bkm:Ref416513591} are common greetings, both of which may be considered compliments, or fixed expressions of greeting after long separation:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Gatambek} ka. | \gll \textbf{Ga-tambek} ka. | \gls I.R-fat/healthy 2S.ABS | \glt ‘You are becoming/became fat/healthy.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ganiwang} ka. | \gll \textbf{Ga-niwang} ka. | \gls I.R-skinny 2S.ABS | \glt ‘You are becoming/became skinny.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref392932747} illustrates a majority class root, ayad ‘be careful’, in the irrealis form in a construction with a verb in happenstantial modality (matellek ‘might get stuck’):
Content 1: \gsrc Pambaļan ko ake na mga duma na \textbf{mag-ayad} tak basi matellek danen an. | \gll Pa-ambaļ-an ko ake na mga duma na \textbf{mag-ayad} tak basi ma-tellek danen an. | \gls T.R-say-APL 1S.ERG 1S.GEN LK PL companion LK I.IR-be.careful because perhaps A.HAP.IR-stick 3P.ABS DEF.M | \glt `I warned my companions to be careful because maybe they might (happen to) get stuck (by a nail in a piece of wood on the ground).’

Knowledge Point: In contrast, magpanaw expresses a more distant future \REF{bkm:Ref63688177}, or more hypothetical irrealis action \REF{bkm:Ref63688194}:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Magpanaw} danen magsimba ta Leganes. | \gll \textbf{Mag-panaw} danen mag-simba ta Leganes. | \gls I.IR-go/walk 3P.ABS I.IR-worship NABS Leganes | \glt ‘They will go to worship in Leganes.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{bkm:Ref392932169} the prefix mag{}- is used twice on minority class verbs in grammatically intransitive constructions, and the prefix m{}- is used once on a minority class verb. In this example, the verbs with mag{}- describe situations that that may or may not happen (\isi{deontic modality} in this case, signaled by the adverbial kinangļan), whereas the verb with m{}- describes the much more inevitable event that the baby will come out.
Content 1: \gsrc Daw bagnes en isya na nanay kinangļan kanen \textbf{magkaan} ta gulay daw \textbf{mag-inem} kanen ta bitamina agod daw \textbf{mwa} bata an biskeg iya na lawa daw madyo ta masakit. | \gll Daw bagnes en isya na nanay kinangļan kanen \textbf{mag-kaan} ta gulay daw \textbf{mag-inem} kanen ta bitamina agod daw \textbf{m-gwa} bata an biskeg iya na lawa daw madyo ta masakit. | \gls if/when pregnant CM one LK mother need 3S.ABS I.IR-eat NABS vegetables and I.IR-drink 3S.ABS NABS vitamins so.that if/when I.V.IR-go.out child DEF.M strong 3S.GEN LK body and far NABS sick | \glt `When a mother is pregnant she should eat vegetables and take (lit. drink) vitamins so that when the baby comes out, his/her body is strong and (s/he) is far from sickness.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref396719550} illustrates what we call the culminative\is{culminative} usage of the irrealis mood. Even though the events of walking and returning home are semantically realis in the story, they are presented as the culminating events in a string of main line events that are closely linked. The events previous to this were about chopping wood and preparing it to carry away. The development in example \REF{bkm:Ref396719550} is about how the Actor carried the wood home, at which point the story ends. This usage is very common following the conjunction daw, and any of the irrealis affixes may function in this way.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \footnotetext{Recall from Chapter 3 that there are both enclitic pronouns that follow their heads, and free pronouns that normally precede their heads. The form din in the first line of this example is the 3\textsc{sg.gen} enclitic pronoun that follows the nominalized verb pag-ipid ‘folded/folding’, while iya is the 3\textsc{sg.gen} free pronoun that precedes apin ‘protective cloth,’ with the linker na intervening. The genitive forms are the same as the ergative forms that occur with verbs inflected as transitive, as is the case with the use of din in the second line of example \REF{bkm:Ref396719550}.}
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref395019310} above also includes a verb with mag{}- in this culminative function: daw maglangoy ‘and began bathing.’ Verbs in the culminative usage definitely express realis events, though they appear in irrealis form. The functional or historical scenario under which this usage could have developed is a topic for future investigation.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: First, most verbal roots take the -en/-on forms, for example, the second bolded verb in \REF{bkm:Ref119939353}, and the bolded verb in \REF{bkm:Ref119939420}. In \chapref{chap:verbclasses-1} these are designated as ``Class VI" roots. There is also a minority class of roots that always take \emptyset{}- as the transitive, irrealis inflection. These are designated as ``Class VII" roots.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Uļa ki nang lugay dya daw \textbf{lubbasen} ta nang bayo ta i aged dili mabasa ... | \gll Uļa ki nang lugay dya daw \textbf{lubbas-en} ta nang bayo ta i aged dili ma-basa{}... | \gls NEG.R 1P.INCL.ABS only/just long.time D4LOC and undress-T.IR 1P.INCL.ERG only/just clothes 1P.INCL.GEN DEF.N so.that NEG.IR A.HAP.IR-wet | \glt `We won’t be long there and we will just take off our clothes so that (they) will not be wet.’

Knowledge Point: Third, the minority class consists of two subclasses, Class VIa and Class VIIb. Class VIIa roots may or may not take an applicative suffix in a grammatically transitive frame, while Class VIIb roots always take an applicative suffix in a grammatically transitive frame. Semantically, Class VIIa consists mostly of verbs of transfer, for example the first bolded verb in \REF{bkm:Ref119939353}, while Class VIIb consists of verbs that always take an applicative suffix in their basic, transitive form (\ref{ex:yourthings} and \ref{ex:yourschooling}). They may occur without the applicative, but only in a grammatically intransitive frame (i.e., detransitive constructions, see example \ref{bkm:Ref447101267} further below, and \chapref{chap:voice}, \sectref{sec:grammaticalrelations}). Semantically, Class VIIb verbs tend strongly to describe activities that involve superficial, incomplete, or invisible effect on the Patient.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Ti \textbf{paakiran} din en bataan ya tak ambaļ ta manakem ya, “\textbf{Kiran} no bataan no. | \gll Ti \textbf{pa-akid-an} din en bata-an ya tak ambaļ ta manakem ya, “∅-\textbf{akid-an} no bata-an no. | \gls so T.R-serve.food-APL 3S.ERG CM child-NR DEF.F because say NABS older DEF.F T.IR-serve.food-APL 2S.ERG child-NR 2S.GEN | \glt `So she served food to the children because the older woman said, “Serve food to your children.”'

Knowledge Point: As mentioned above, for Class VI roots, the applicative -an overrides -en/-on, thus leaving “zero” (a conspicuous absence of affixation) as the indicator of the transitive, irrealis inflection (see \chapref{chap:stemformingprocesses}, \sectref{sec:applicative-an} for further discussion). Thus the applicative suffix forms a stem that belongs to Class VII. This makes some semantic sense since the applicative indicates a superficially, invisibly or partially affected Undergoer (see \chapref{chap:voice}, \sectref{sec:applicativevoice}), and most verbs in Class VII also involve less than fully affected Patients as Undergoers (see \tabref{tab:rootsthattaketwodistincttransitiveirrealisinflections-1} in \chapref{chap:verbclasses-1}). Example \REF{bkm:Ref447101267} illustrates the Class VII root akid, ‘to serve food’, in the basic transitive form (realis modality), and in the irrealis detransitive form:
Content 1: \gsrc Ti \textbf{paakiran} din en bataan ya tak ambaļ ta manakem ya, “\textbf{Kiran} no bataan no. | \gll Ti \textbf{pa-akid-an} din en bata-an ya tak ambaļ ta manakem ya, “∅-\textbf{akid-an} no bata-an no. | \gls so T.R-serve.food-APL 3S.ERG CM child-NR DEF.F because say NABS older DEF.F T.IR-serve.food-APL 2S.ERG child-NR 2S.GEN | \glt `So she served food to the children because the older woman said, “Serve food to your children.”'

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref499555402} illustrates the root legem ‘to dye’ that normally takes -en as its transitive, irrealis form, but in this example it occurs with the applicative suffix, which overrides -en, thus leaving \emptyset{}- as the exponent of the transitive, irrealis inflection:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Note that -an itself cannot be the marker of the transitive, irrealis inflection because it also occurs in realis contexts (see \ref{bkm:Ref120012965} and many other examples thoughout this grammar). On the other hand, “zero” as a marker of transitive, irrealis inflection is independently attested for a large lexical class of roots (Class VII, see \chapref{chap:verbclasses-1}, \tabref{tab:rootsthattaketwodistincttransitiveirrealisinflections-1}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nademdeman} din arey din Lisga. | \gll \textbf{Na-demdem-an} din arey din Lisga.\footnotemark{} | \gls A.HAP.R-remember-APL 3S.ERG friend 3S.GEN fire.ant | \glt ‘S/he remembered his friend Fire Ant.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref447002651} and \REF{bkm:Ref119941331} illustrate the verb beļad ‘to dry X in the sun’. In \REF{bkm:Ref447002651} it occurs with the normal transitive irrealis suffix -en and in example \REF{bkm:Ref119941331} the same verb occurs with i{}- and the meaning is that it is necessary to dry the cassava after soaking it so that it does not go bad.
Content 1: \gsrc Dayon kamangen sinaksak an na derse daw \textbf{beļaren.} | \gll Dayon kamang-en s<in>aksak an na derse daw \textbf{beļad-en.} | \gls right.away get-T.IR <NR.RES>chop DEF.M LK small.PL and dry.in.sun-T.IR | \glt ‘Right away get the chopped parts that are small and dry (them in the sun).’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gsrc Dayon kamangen sinaksak an na derse daw \textbf{beļaren.} | \gll Dayon kamang-en s<in>aksak an na derse daw \textbf{beļad-en.} | \gls right.away get-T.IR <NR.RES>chop DEF.M LK small.PL and dry.in.sun-T.IR | \glt ‘Right away get the chopped parts that are small and dry (them in the sun).’

Knowledge Point: All Class VII roots (mostly verbs of transfer) may occur with the i{}- with the same deontic meaning illustrated above. The following are some examples from the corpus. Examples \REF{bkm:Ref447005121} and \REF{bkm:Ref119941404} illustrate the verb batang ‘to put X somewhere’. In example \REF{bkm:Ref447005121} the same root occurs in the unmarked transitive irrealis form meaning ‘will place the liver (absolutive) of the chick on the diaphragm of the person who is sick’ and in \REF{bkm:Ref119941404} it occurs with the i{}- prefix meaning ‘I must put the thorns (absolutive) on the banana plant.’
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Mamang a ta mga tellek daw \textbf{ibatang} ko naan ta lawa ta saging aged dili ka kapanaog. | \gll M-kamang a ta mga tellek daw \textbf{ibatang} ko naan ta lawa ta saging aged dili ka ka-panaog. | \gls I.V.IR-get 1S.ABS NABS PL thorn and T.DEON-put 1S.ERG SPAT.DEF NABS body NABS banana so.that NEG.IR 2S.ABS I.HAP-come.down | \glt `I need to get some thorns and put (them) on the trunk of the banana plant so that you can’t come down.’
Content 4: \gsrc Mamang a ta mga tellek daw \textbf{ibatang} ko naan ta lawa ta saging aged dili ka kapanaog. | \gll M-kamang a ta mga tellek daw \textbf{ibatang} ko naan ta lawa ta saging aged dili ka ka-panaog. | \gls I.V.IR-get 1S.ABS NABS PL thorn and T.DEON-put 1S.ERG SPAT.DEF NABS body NABS banana so.that NEG.IR 2S.ABS I.HAP-come.down | \glt `I need to get some thorns and put (them) on the trunk of the banana plant so that you can’t come down.’

Knowledge Point: The implication in \REF{bkm:Ref119941404} is that the speaker is compelled by the need to prevent the addressee from climbing down the banana plant.
Content 1: \gsrc Mamang a ta mga tellek daw \textbf{ibatang} ko naan ta lawa ta saging aged dili ka kapanaog. | \gll M-kamang a ta mga tellek daw \textbf{ibatang} ko naan ta lawa ta saging aged dili ka ka-panaog. | \gls I.V.IR-get 1S.ABS NABS PL thorn and T.DEON-put 1S.ERG SPAT.DEF NABS body NABS banana so.that NEG.IR 2S.ABS I.HAP-come.down | \glt `I need to get some thorns and put (them) on the trunk of the banana plant so that you can’t come down.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref460145354} through \REF{bkm:Ref447269492} illustrate verbs that can occur with i- functioning in an applicative frame, in which case a deontic sense is possible, but not necessary. This function is not very productive, and only occurs with certain verbs that take -en as their basic, transitive irrealis form-mostly verbs that involve some special instrument. For example, the verb asod ‘to pound grain’ implies a specific instrument, aļļo ‘pestle’. For this and similar verbs, i- selects the instrument as the absolutive argument (instrumental voice-see \chapref{chap:voice}, \sectref{sec:instrumentalvoice}), though with \textit{{}-en} and the other transitive affixes, this verb selects the theme as the absolutive:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Iasod} ko aļļo i na buat din. | \gll \textbf{I-asod} ko aļļo i na buat din. | \gls T.DEON-pound 1S.ERG pestle DEF.N LK make 3S.ERG | \glt ‘I will pound (something) with the pestle that s/he made.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Iakid} a no ta kan-en. | \gll \textbf{I-akid} a no ta kan-en. | \gls T.DEON.APL-serve.food 1S.ABS 2S.ERG NABS rice | \glt ‘Serve some rice for/to me.’

Knowledge Point: The verb akid also describes transfer (‘serve X to Y’). Therefore, for this verb, i{}- may also select a beneficiary/recipient as the absolutive argument, as illustrated in \REF{bkm:Ref447269492}:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Iakid} a no ta kan-en. | \gll \textbf{I-akid} a no ta kan-en. | \gls T.DEON.APL-serve.food 1S.ABS 2S.ERG NABS rice | \glt ‘Serve some rice for/to me.’

Knowledge Point: Furthermore, in example \REF{bkm:Ref119940330} i- is functioning in a nominalized dependent clause, rather than the predicate in a main clause (as indicated by the prenominal case marker ta occurring immediately before the verb). These are the only examples in the corpus of i- occuring in an applicative frame.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref392922279} illustrates the happenstantial realis prefix na- in its basic usage on a non-volitional intransitive verb describing an event on the story line of a narrative:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nuļog} a ta kabaw tak gadļagan tudo kabaw an. | \gll \textbf{Na-uļog} a ta kabaw tak ga-dļagan tudo kabaw an. | \gls A.HAP.R-fall 1S.ABS NABS carabao because I.R-run intense carabao DEF.M. | \glt ‘I fell off the carabao because the carabao was running hard.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref448318853} and \REF{bkm:Ref120012965} illustrate na{}- in its usage on transitive experiential verbs of perception and cognition on the story line of a narrative:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nakita} din ake na mangngod na nalemmes. | \gll \textbf{Na-kita} din ake na mangngod na na-lemmes. | \gls A.HAP.R-see 3S.ERG 1S.GEN LK younger.sibling LK A.HAP.R-drown | \glt ‘He saw my younger sibling who drowned.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Nademdeman} din arey din Lisga. | \gll \textbf{Na-demdem-an} din arey din Lisga.\footnotemark{} | \gls A.HAP.R-remember-APL 3S.ERG friend 3S.GEN fire.ant | \glt ‘S/he remembered his friend Fire Ant.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref508296047} illustrates an emotion verb in its default usage:
Content 1: \gsrc Kanen i \textbf{nadlek} gid tak uļa gid duma. | \gll Kanen i \textbf{na-adlek} gid tak uļa gid duma. | \gls 3S.ABS DEF.N A.HAP.R-aftaid INT because NEG.R INT companion | \glt ‘He was really afraid because there was no companion.’

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{bkm:Ref396387524} the happenstantial na{}- expresses a realized dynamic event that just happened without anyone intentionally trying to make it happen. This sentence could also express a realized capability, ‘they were able to (intentionally) meet’, but the discourse context makes it clear that the intended meaning is happenstance. It is also not perfect aspect because it asserts the event rather than a state resulting from an earlier event:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nasugat} danen bata i ta iran na maistro na ngaran din Pedro na galin Puerto | \gll \textbf{Na-sugat} danen bata i ta iran na maistro na ngaran din Pedro na ga-alin Puerto… | \gls A.HAP.R-meet 3P.ERG child DEF.N NABS 3P.GEN LK teacher LK name 3S.GEN Pedro LK I.R-from Puerto | \glt `They happened to meet the son of their teacher whose name is Pedro who came from Puerto.’

Knowledge Point: In examples \REF{bkm:Ref396387548} and \REF{bkm:Ref119941722} na{}- expresses a realized capability: ‘was able to.’ In this case, happenstance is not likely since “catching the ball” and “carrying the child” are not situations that occur without intention. And again, they are not perfect in aspect since they assert events rather than resultant states:
Content 1: \gsrc Paglabyog ta pangka ta bula ya, \textbf{nasaļap} dayon ta princesa. | \gll Pag-labyog ta pangka ta bula ya, \textbf{na-saļap} dayon ta princesa. | \gls NR.ACT-throw NABS frog NABS ball DEF.F A.HAP.R-catch immediately NABS princess | \glt `When the frog threw the ball (lit. the frog’s throwing of the ball), the princess immediately was able to catch it.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tapos bata ya \textbf{nadaļa} gid ta tallo ya na ayam | \gll Tapos bata ya \textbf{na-daļa} gid ta tallo ya na ayam… | \gls then child DEF.F A.HAP.R-take/carry INT NABS three DEF.F LK dog | \glt ‘Then as for the child the three dogs were able to carry (him) away.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref392922782} illustrates na- in a dynamic transitive construction expressing perfect aspect. Note that the Actor, the parrot fish, is marked as non-absolutive. This indicates that the absolutive argument is the Patient, the butterfly fish’s mouth. Happenstantial is used in this case to indicate a state that resulted from an event that happened earlier in the order of events on the storyline, and therefore may be understood as perfect in aspect:
Content 1: \gsrc Kalibangbang an a daw makita ta man en anduni ļangkaw en baba din an tak \textbf{nakemes} ta tuļ{}-ungan. | \gll Kalibangbang an a daw ma-kita ta man en anduni ļangkaw en baba din an tak \textbf{na-kemes} ta tuļ{}-ungan. | \gls butterfly DEF.M CTR if/when A.HAP.IR-see 1P.INCL.ERG too CM now/today long CM mouth 3S.GEN DEF.M because A.HAP.R-squeeze NABS parrot.fish | \glt `The butterfly fish if we could see (it/them) indeed now/today, its mouth is long because the parrot fish has squeezed (it).’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref440036963} and \REF{bkm:Ref119941820} illustrate intransitive clauses with ma{}- in its primary usage from the corpus:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Marwad} ate na ambaļ na Kagayanen ta pila na adlaw. | \gll \textbf{Ma-duwad} ate na ambaļ na Kagayanen ta pila na adlaw. | \gls A.HAP.IR-lose 1P.INCL.GEN LK say LK Kagayanen NABS few LK sun/day | \glt ‘Our Kagayanen language \textbf{will} \textbf{be} \textbf{lost} in a short time (lit. in a few days).’
Content 2: \gsrc Daw sikad man an inog nangka i, lugay \textbf{makamang} iya an na bao. | \gll Daw sikad man an inog nangka i, lugay \textbf{ma-kamang} iya an na bao. | \gls if/when very EMPH ATT ripe jackfruit DEF.N long.time A.HAP.IR-remove 3S.GEN DEF.M LK odor | \glt `When the jackfruit is really ripe, (it takes) a long time for its odor \textbf{to} \textbf{dissipate}.’

Knowledge Point: \hspace*{-.7pt}Examples \REF{bkm:Ref119353744} and \REF{bkm:Ref119353747} illustrate semantically transitive\is{semantic transitivity}\is{transitivity!semantic} experiential verbs with ma{}- in its primary usage:
Content 1: \gsrc Tama man \textbf{makita} no na mga klasi mga ayep naan ta patag. \textbf{Makita} no baka, kabayo daw kanding. | \gll Tama man \textbf{ma-kita} no na mga klasi mga ayep naan ta patag. \textbf{Ma-kita} no baka, kabayo daw kanding. | \gls many too A.HAP.IR-see 2S.ERG LK PL kinds PL animal SPAT.DEF NABS plain A.HAP.IR-see 2S.ERG cow horse and goat | \glt `The kinds of animals that you \textbf{will/might/can} \textbf{also} \textbf{see} on the plain are many. You \textbf{will/might/can} \textbf{see} cows, horses and goats.’
Content 2: \gsrc Yi na suļat para nang kaon agod \textbf{mademdeman} no man yaken i. | \gll Yi na suļat para nang kaon agod \textbf{ma-demdem-an} no man yaken i. | \gls D1ABS LK letter for only/just 2S.ABS so.that A.HAP.IR-remember-APL 2S.ERG too 1S.ABS DEF.N | \glt `This letter is just for you so that you \textbf{will} \textbf{remember} me too.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref448320715} and \REF{bkm:Ref123671980} illustrate the happenstantial irrealis prefix ma- expressing a potential capability: `will be able to' or `can':
Content 1: \gsrc Daw \textbf{madakep} ta kaw, tekteken ta kaw. | \gll Daw \textbf{ma-dakep} ta kaw, tektek-en ta kaw. | \gls if/when A.HAP.IR-catch 1S.ERG 2S.ABS chop.fine-T.IR 1S.ERG 2S.ABS | \glt ‘If \textbf{I} \textbf{am} \textbf{able} \textbf{to} \textbf{catch} \textbf{you}, I will chop you up fine.’
Content 2: \gsrc Manang, daw pwidi nang, inta atagan a no ta address Maria para \textbf{masuļatan} ko kanen ya. | \gll Manang, daw pwidi nang, inta ∅-atag-an a no ta address Maria para \textbf{ma-suļat-an} ko kanen ya. | \gls older.sister if/when can only OPT T.IR-give-APL 1S.ABS 2S.ERG NABS address Maria for A.HAP.IR-write-APL 1S.ERG 3S.ABS DEF.F | \glt `Older sister, if/when just possible, give me the address of Maria so that \textbf{I} \textbf{can} \textbf{write} to her.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref119942002} through \REF{bkm:Ref89078422} illustrate what we are calling the hypothetical usage of the prefix ma-. In this usage, predicates inflected with ma{}- describe situations that may occur from time to time, but no specific actual event. This usage occurs frequently in expository texts.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Masimba} anay danen an daw magprusisyon na daļa a santos na Santo Ninyo palibot ta banwa | \gll \textbf{Ma-simba} anay danen an daw mag-prusisyon na daļa a santos na Santo Ninyo pa-libot ta banwa… | \gls A.HAP.IR-church first/for-a-while 3P.ABS DEF.M and I.IR-procession LK take/carry INJ statue LK Holy Child T.R-around NABS town/country | \glt `They \textbf{go} \textbf{to} \textbf{church} and go in a procession carrying the Santo Ninyo statue taking it around the town…’
Content 2: \gsrc Kan-o na timpo daw \textbf{malarga} mga bļangay o lansa man galiid gid ti na puļo | \gll Kan-o na timpo daw \textbf{ma-larga} mga bļangay o lansa man ga-liid gid ti na puļo… | \gls previous LK time/season if/when A.HAP.IR-depart PL 2.masted.boat or launch also T.R-pass.close.by INT D1NABS LK island | \glt `In previous times, if/when two-masted boats or launches \textbf{would} \textbf{depart}, (they) passed close by this island…’

Knowledge Point: If the first verb in the construct illustrated in \REF{bkm:Ref89078422} were marga, which consists of m{}- ‘dynamic, intransitive, irrealis’ plus the root larga, then the sentence would imply a more immediate event ‘(the launch) will purposely depart’. The verb form maglarga is the general irrealis form, open to multiple interpretations, or some more distant future event. The form malarga describes events that happened many times in the past. Irrealis modality is appropriate because no particular event is asserted.
Content 1: \gsrc Kan-o na timpo daw \textbf{malarga} mga bļangay o lansa man galiid gid ti na puļo | \gll Kan-o na timpo daw \textbf{ma-larga} mga bļangay o lansa man ga-liid gid ti na puļo… | \gls previous LK time/season if/when A.HAP.IR-depart PL 2.masted.boat or launch also T.R-pass.close.by INT D1NABS LK island | \glt `In previous times, if/when two-masted boats or launches \textbf{would} \textbf{depart}, (they) passed close by this island…’

Knowledge Point: The happenstantial realis prefix naka- only occurs in grammatically intransitive constructions in which the controller of the situation is expressed in the absolutive case. Normally naka- and its irrealis counterpart maka- describe animate activity or activity that is “animate-like.” Example \REF{bkm:Ref447862310} illustrates naka{}- expressing perfect aspect (a state resulting from an earlier event). If these two verbs, agi ‘to pass’ and tinir ‘to stay’, were on the storyline they would have the dynamic intransitive prefix ga{}- instead of naka\nobreakdash-. This is a fairly prototypical usage of naka-:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref447862310} contrasts with the usage of na- in, for example, \REF{bkm:Ref447862443} above in that the events of passing through and staying in \REF{bkm:Ref447862310} are volitional---they are something the absolutive participant does, rather than something that “happens to” the absolutive. For this reason, we say that naka{}- (and maka{}-) are “Actor-oriented”. Falling off the carabao in \REF{bkm:Ref447862443}, on the other hand, is “Undergoer-orien\-ted”---it is something that “happens to” the absolutive marked participant. However, in \REF{bkm:Ref447862310}, neither situation is on the storyline of the narrative. They are both “flashbacks” to earlier events that have relevance to the current narrative, but which do not themselves advance the storyline. For this reason a perfect aspect interpretation is appropriate. Furthermore, \REF{bkm:Ref447862310} contrasts with \REF{bkm:Ref448318853} through \REF{bkm:Ref392922782} in that these earlier examples are in transitive frames, whereas naka- always appears in an intransitive or detransitive frame in which the absolutive refers to the Controller.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 7: \gsrc \textbf{Nakita} din ake na mangngod na nalemmes. | \gll \textbf{Na-kita} din ake na mangngod na na-lemmes. | \gls A.HAP.R-see 3S.ERG 1S.GEN LK younger.sibling LK A.HAP.R-drown | \glt ‘He saw my younger sibling who drowned.’
Content 8: \gsrc Kalibangbang an a daw makita ta man en anduni ļangkaw en baba din an tak \textbf{nakemes} ta tuļ{}-ungan. | \gll Kalibangbang an a daw ma-kita ta man en anduni ļangkaw en baba din an tak \textbf{na-kemes} ta tuļ{}-ungan. | \gls butterfly DEF.M CTR if/when A.HAP.IR-see 1P.INCL.ERG too CM now/today long CM mouth 3S.GEN DEF.M because A.HAP.R-squeeze NABS parrot.fish | \glt `The butterfly fish if we could see (it/them) indeed now/today, its mouth is long because the parrot fish has squeezed (it).’

Knowledge Point: Concerning example \REF{bkm:Ref448309255}, the event expressed by sangga, ‘bump into’, occurred previously in the story expressed with the form nasanggaan ‘happened to bump into’. In that case, the implication is that the fish accidentally bumped into a limestone formation after having swum off quickly without regard to the direction he was going. Then example \REF{bkm:Ref448309255} occurs at the end of the story with naka- indicating that the parrot fish had some responsibility for running into the rock because he had so mindlessly swum off. The moral of the story is overtly stated as “think before reacting”. We have attempted to capture this assertion of impulsiveness on the part of the parrot fish in the free translation with the English expression “had gone and banged . . .”:
Content 1: \gsrc A, yon en na anduni tuļ-ungan i daw makita ta naan dagat, takong din an buksoļ, unti, tenged na \textbf{nakasangga} kanen ta manunggoļ. | \gll A, yon en na anduni tuļ{}-ungan i daw ma-kita ta naan dagat, takong din an buksoļ, unti, tenged na \textbf{naka-sangga} kanen ta manunggoļ. | \gls INJ D3ABS CM LK now/today parrot.fish DEF.N if/when A.HAP.IR-see 1P.INCL.ERG SPAT.DEF sea forehead 3S.GEN DEF.M lump DlLOC.PR because LK I.HAP.R-bump.into 3S.ABS NABS limestone | \glt `Well, that (is the reason) now/today that the parrot fish when we see (it/them) in the sea, his forehead is lumped, here, because he (has gone and) banged into a limestone formation.’
Content 2: \gsrc A, yon en na anduni tuļ-ungan i daw makita ta naan dagat, takong din an buksoļ, unti, tenged na \textbf{nakasangga} kanen ta manunggoļ. | \gll A, yon en na anduni tuļ{}-ungan i daw ma-kita ta naan dagat, takong din an buksoļ, unti, tenged na \textbf{naka-sangga} kanen ta manunggoļ. | \gls INJ D3ABS CM LK now/today parrot.fish DEF.N if/when A.HAP.IR-see 1P.INCL.ERG SPAT.DEF sea forehead 3S.GEN DEF.M lump DlLOC.PR because LK I.HAP.R-bump.into 3S.ABS NABS limestone | \glt `Well, that (is the reason) now/today that the parrot fish when we see (it/them) in the sea, his forehead is lumped, here, because he (has gone and) banged into a limestone formation.’

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{bkm:Ref392929987} nakabantaw expresses a realized ability: ‘we were able to see’:
Content 1: \gsrc Ta seled ta limma na adlaw \textbf{nakabantaw} \textbf{kay} ta isya na bukid ta Panay. | \gll Ta seled ta limma na adlaw \textbf{naka-bantaw} \textbf{kay} ta isya na bukid ta Panay. | \gls NABS within NABS five LK day/sun I.HAP.R-look.far.away 1P.EXCL.ABS NABS one LK mountain NABS Panay | \glt `Within five days we were able/managed to spot far away one mountain on Panay.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref447897963} is particularly interesting in that it illustrates the same verb, mati ‘to hear/listen’ both in the dynamic form, and the intransitive happenstantial:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In the first instance of the verb mati in \REF{bkm:Ref447897963}, gamati, the dynamic form implies the Actors were intentionally listening to the drama. In the second instance, nakamati, they happened to hear something, not intentionally, but only experientially. English expresses this intentional/non-intentional distinction in the two lexical verbs, listen and hear, whereas Kagayanen accomplishes the same semantic distinction by exploiting the morphological contrast between dynamic and happenstantial modalities. The form namatian would require the Actor to be in the ergative case, and the Undergoer in the absolutive, and since this excerpt is a series of events describing what the main protagonists were doing, the Actor-oriented intransitive form nakamati is more appropriate.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref448405038} illustrates the cognition verbs intindi ‘understand’, and sat-em ‘comprehend’ in their normal usages with naka. Other cognition verbs in this group include isip ‘think’, demdem ‘remember’, and lipat ‘forget’:
Content 1: \gsrc A ginikanan an a na uļa \textbf{nakaintindi}, uļa \textbf{nakasat-em,} mambaļ en dayon, “Indya kwarta no ya?" | \gll A ginikanan an a na uļa \textbf{naka-intindi}, uļa \textbf{naka-sat-em,} m-ambaļ en dayon, “Indya kwarta no ya?" | \gls INJ parent DEF.M CTR LK NEG.R I.HAP.R-understand NEG.R I.HAP.R-comprehend I.V.IR-say CM immediately where money 2S.GEN DEF.F | \glt `Well, parents who \textbf{do} \textbf{not} \textbf{understand}, \textbf{do} \textbf{not} \textbf{comprehend} will say immediately, “Where is your money?”' (In the context of this sentence high school graduates tell their parents that they want to go to college, and this is the parents’ response.)

Knowledge Point: The prefix maka{}- is the irrealis counterpart of naka-. It also occurs only in intransitive frames in which the single argument is animate, or an inanimate entity that acts in an animate way. Example \REF{bkm:Ref447962976} is a near prototypical example of the use of maka{}-:
Content 1: \gsrc Kanen \textbf{makabali} ta sundang daw iya na makagat. | \gll Kanen \textbf{maka-bali} ta sundang daw iya na ma-kagat. | \gls 3S.ABS I.HAP.IR-break NABS machete if/when 3S.GEN LK A.HAP.IR-bite \glt ‘HE (coconut crab) can break a machete if (it is the thing) he bites.’

Knowledge Point: If the prefix ma{}- were used here, it would be extremely awkward, and could only mean “\textsc{him} the machete broke,” since with ma{}- the absolutive has to be the Undergoer. To preserve the basic semantics using ma{}- the argument structure would need to change in order to make it clear that the machete is the Patient. Thus, the first part of \REF{bkm:Ref447962976} can be considered a detransitive counterpart of \REF{bkm:Ref447963964} (see \chapref{chap:voice} for a discussion of detransitive constructions):
Content 1: \gsrc Kanen \textbf{makabali} ta sundang daw iya na makagat. | \gll Kanen \textbf{maka-bali} ta sundang daw iya na ma-kagat. | \gls 3S.ABS I.HAP.IR-break NABS machete if/when 3S.GEN LK A.HAP.IR-bite \glt ‘HE (coconut crab) can break a machete if (it is the thing) he bites.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Mabali} din sundang an. | \gll \textbf{Ma-bali} din sundang an. | \gls A.HAP.IR-break 3S.ERG machete DEF.M | \glt ‘S/he can break the machete.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref447963006} illustrates another fairly prototypical use of maka-:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The verb tabang, ‘to help’, is one that requires the applicative suffix in its basic transitive usage (see \chapref{chap:verbclasses-1}, \sectref{sec:volitionaltransitiveroots}). Since there is no applicative on tabang in \REF{bkm:Ref447963006}, it must be detransitive, and therefore is the counterpart of the transitive construction illustrated in \REF{bkm:Ref448035920}. Example \REF{bkm:Ref120014772} illustrates the same verb form in the text corpus:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Matabangan} no imo na mga ginikanan. | \gll \textbf{Ma-tabang-an} no imo na mga ginikanan. | \gls HAP.IR-help-APL 2S.ERG 2S.GEN LK PL parent | \glt ‘You can help your parents.”

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref392930212} and \REF{bkm:Ref120014811} illustrate maka{}- with the experiential verbs kita ‘to see/find’ and singngot ‘to smell s.t.’ With perception and cognition verbs, naka{}- and maka{}- are the normal detransitive (or “Actor voice”) forms that correspond to na{}-/ma{}- in a transitive frame:\footnote{For this reason, the ka component of naka{}- and maka{}- may be considered an explicit marker of an antipassive construction. However, we find scant independent evidence that this ka is a separate morpheme, for example, it is not used in any other modalities to express an antipassive (our detransitive) construction.}.
Content 1: \gsrc Pangamuyuan ta kaw nang na kabay \textbf{makakita} ka man ta ubra na dayad. | \gll ∅-Pangamuyo-an ta kaw nang na kabay \textbf{maka-kita} ka man ta ubra na dayad. | \gls T.IR-pray-APL 1S.ERG 2S.ABS ony/just LK may.it.be I.HAP.IR-see 2S.ABS TOO NABS work LK good | \glt `I will just pray for you that you may be able to find work that is good.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tak, daw naan a agi ta dapit abagat i, \textbf{makasingngot} kanen ta bao ko. | \gll Tak, daw naan a agi ta dapit abagat i, \textbf{maka-singngot} kanen ta bao ko. | \gls because if/when SPAT.DEF 1S.ABS pass NABS direction south(west) DEF.N I.HAP.IR-smell 3S.ABS NABS odor 1S.GEN | \glt `For, if I pass in the direction of south(west), he (a wild pig) will be able to smell my odor.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref447964968} through \REF{bkm:Ref120014968} illustrate maka{}- with semantically intransitive\is{semantic transitivity}\is{transitivity!semantic} volitional verb stems. These cannot be considered detransitives, because there is no Undergoer, and no transitive counterpart in which the Actor is ergative. They are semantically intransitive\is{semantic transitivity}\is{transitivity!semantic} concepts in which the only participant is an Actor, rather than an Undergoer. The dynamic irrealis affixes for these verbs are m{}- or mag{}- as in megbeng/magtegeng, miling/mag-iling, and magbakasyon. In these examples the happenstantial maka{}- expresses potential ability:
Content 1: \gsrc Uļa aren timpo na \textbf{makategbeng} naan ki kaon. | \gll Uļa aren timpo na \textbf{maka-tegbeng} naan ki kaon. | \gls NEG.R 1S.ABS time LK I.HAP.IR-go.down SPAT.DEF {obl.p} 2s | \glt ‘I have no time that I can go down to you.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In the external motivation usage, ka- expresses that there is some external factor that motivates, or enables (prevents in the case of negative situations) the controller to carry out the activity. For example, in \REF{bkm:Ref389056631} a wooden cane enables the actor to walk, and in \REF{bkm:Ref396746244} fear prevents the actor from speaking:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{bkm:Ref396747208}, catching fish is enabled by good luck:
Content 1: \gsrc Ta dayad na panwirtién asta a magpailis ta Barangay Nusa, \textbf{kasubbad} pa ta darwa buok... | \gll Ta dayad na pang-swirti-én asta a mag-pa-ilis ta Barangay Nusa, \textbf{ka-subbad} pa ta darwa buok... | \gls NABS good LK NR-luck-NR until 1S.ABS I.IR-CAUS-shallow.sea NABS community Nusa I.HAP-catch.fish INC NABS two piece | \glt `With much good luck, even when I was beginning to go to the shallow sea (along the shore) of the community of Nusa, I was able to catch two more pieces (fish)...’

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{bkm:Ref447898317}, ka{}-, expresses the idea that his feeling lonely is motivated by the fact that the addressee is absent.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref120018997} illustrates external motivation ka- in a negative context. The ability to go home is prevented by strong winds and large waves.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The prefix ka- also has an inferential\is{inferential} usage. In the context of example \REF{bkm:Ref447986985}, a fish sees a ship coming and tells all the other fish to hide. After the fish have hidden, example \REF{bkm:Ref447986985} occurs, expressing the inference that the boat most likely has passed by. In the sentence after that, the fish all look up and see that the boat in fact is moving away fast. An enablement interpretation of \REF{bkm:Ref447986985} is excluded by native speakers. In this context, the speaker (the fish) infers that the situation expressed by the root is true because of the external fact that much time has passed.
Content 1: \gsrc Anduni \textbf{kalambay} en bļangay ya en. | \gll Anduni \textbf{ka-lambay} en bļangay ya en. | \gls now/today I.HAP-pass.by CM 2.masted.boat DEF.F CM | \glt ‘Now the boat (must have) passed by.’ (Or ‘Now the boat most-likely/feasibly/predictably has passed by.’)
Content 2: \gsrc Anduni \textbf{kalambay} en bļangay ya en. | \gll Anduni \textbf{ka-lambay} en bļangay ya en. | \gls now/today I.HAP-pass.by CM 2.masted.boat DEF.F CM | \glt ‘Now the boat (must have) passed by.’ (Or ‘Now the boat most-likely/feasibly/predictably has passed by.’)
Content 3: \gsrc Anduni \textbf{kalambay} en bļangay ya en. | \gll Anduni \textbf{ka-lambay} en bļangay ya en. | \gls now/today I.HAP-pass.by CM 2.masted.boat DEF.F CM | \glt ‘Now the boat (must have) passed by.’ (Or ‘Now the boat most-likely/feasibly/predictably has passed by.’)

Knowledge Point: In the narrative from which \REF{bkm:Ref396802277} is extracted, Pedro’s father was killed, and since Pedro is the son, of course he had heard about it. This is clearly inferential modality rather than abilitative.
Content 1: \gsrc Bata din na Pedro naan ta Puerto \textbf{kabati} ta sakit na kamatayen ta iya na palangga na tatay. | \gll Bata din na Pedro naan ta Puerto \textbf{ka-bati} ta sakit na kamatayen ta iya na palangga na tatay. | \gls child 3S.GEN LK Pedro SPAT.DEF NABS Puerto I.HAP-hear.news NABS painful LK death NABS 3S.GEN LK love LK father | \glt `His son Pedro in Puerto must have heard the news about the painful death of his beloved father.’ (Or most-likely/feasibly/predictably he has heard the news…)

Knowledge Point: It is clear that this omission of prefixes is “optional” for two reasons. First, such omission never results in ambiguity—speakers are always able to supply the missing form based on contextual factors. Second, sometimes inflectional prefixes do appear in these contexts, with no apparent variation in meaning. A full discourse study may be needed to determine whether there is a consistent pattern as to when prefixes are omitted versus when they are retained. Since most of the examples in this grammar are from natural texts, many have omitted prefixes. We have not edited or flagged these in any way, unless the omission is important to the point being illustrated in the example. Examples \REF{bkm:Ref119307770} and \REF{bkm:Ref119307774} illustrate affix omission, with the ellipsis character (…) in place of the omitted affix:
Content 1: \gsrc Indi no imo \textbf{kamanga} mga blawan an Pedro? | \gll Indi no imo …\textbf{-kamang-a} mga blawan an Pedro? | \gls where 2S.ERG EMPH T.R-get-XC PL gold DEF.M Pedro | \glt ‘Where did you get the gold, Pedro!?'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The following examples illustrate the root, dala, ‘take/carry’, both with \REF{bkm:Ref394992438} and without \REF{bkm:Ref394992440} the overt transitive realis prefix. The argument structure frame (Actor-ergative and Undergoer-absolutive) makes it clear that both examples are transitive, and the contexts make it clear that both are realis:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Padaļa} din iya na bata naan ta iran na baļay. | \gll \textbf{Pa-daļa} din iya na bata naan ta iran na baļay. | \gls T.R-bring/take 3S.ERG 3S.GEN LK child SPAT.DEF NABS 3P.GEN LK house | \glt ‘She took her child to their house.’ (Her child had died, so she carried her back to their house.)
Content 2: Not found
